en: Female voices in speech recognition technology

Yet lead scientists on the teams that developed both the Oxford and the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines are women!

We're guessing that you've heard of: Mary Anning, Dorothy Hodgkin, Marie Curie, Rosalind Franklin, Jane Goodall. 

Here are some other notable names of pioneers that aren't mentioned as often male counterparts:

Computer science and Fields Medalist 

  • Grace Murray Hopper - pioneered computer and programming language development  
  • Edith Clarke - pioneering electrical engineer at the turn of the 20th century 
  • Maryam Mirzakhani is an Iranian American mathematician and the first woman to be awarded the Fields Medal mathematics prize for her work in the field of geometry and dynamical systems 

Women of colour 

  • Katherine Johnson - one of NASA's human computer wizards that enabled manned missions to the moon, including the moon landing.
  • Ellen Ochoa - the first Hispanic woman to go to space 
  • Gladys West - whose calculations led to Global Position System (GPS)

Contributions to nuclear physics 

  • Calutron girls – enriched uranium as part of the Manhattan Project when wartime labour shortages meant women were recruited out of high school  
  • Lise Meitner – Germany's own Marie Curie, physicist who worked on fission and had to flee the Nazis because of her Jewish decent  
  • Maria Sibylla Merian – naturalist who drew botanicals and spent a lot of time in Amsterdam 
  • Barbara McClintock – first suggested epigenetics, her work on jumping genes in maize was not recognised for a long time until a Nobel prize in 1983.
  • Gabriela González - astrophysicist spokeswoman for the LIGO team Physics World that announced as the 2016 Breakthrough of the Year for “their revolutionary, first ever direct observations of gravitational waves.”
How many female scientists can you name?
Feijia Yin evaluates the climate impact of future aircraft propulsion technologies.
Amy Thomas investigates historical connections between gender, well-being and workplace design.
Odette Scharenborg works on improving and diversifying automatic speech processing technologies.
studies how robots and virtual reality can be employed to improve neurorehabilitation patients after brain injuries.

Stay true to yourself even when things don’t work out the way you hoped they would.

Advice for the next generation of female scientists Believe in yourself and stay true to yourself even when things don't work out the way you hoped they would work out. You know best what makes your clock tick. Follow that intuition when you make decisions, start or end research projects and collaborations, set your career path, etc., but take advice from others because there is a wealth of experience and knowledge in the people around you that they are happy to share if you ask. Lastly, treat others as you want others to treat you.

Research's Impact on Society

Speech-driven technology is used extensively. Think of the smart speaker in your living room, but also of all the possibilities that speech-driven technology offers in care and independence for the elderly and disabled. But... the current software only works effectively if the person speaking has reasonably standard pronunciation, so does not have a speech impediment, and speaks one of the approximately 2% of the worldâ€™s languages for which speech-driven technology is available. Odetteâ€™s aim is to build human speech-processing inspired speech technology for everyone, irrespective of the way and the language the person speaks.

Biography

Odette Scharenborg is an Associate Professor and Delft Technology Fellow at the Multimedia Computing Group (EEMCS) working on human speech-processing inspired automatic speech processing (PhD 2005, Radboud University). She was awarded NWO Talent, Veni, and Vidi fellowships. She is a board member of the International Speech Communication Association (ISCA) and the IEEE Speech and Language Technical Committee (SLTC), and serves as a European Commission expert consultant on Language Technologies. Odette is an active proponent of diversity and inclusion both at TU Delft and in her research community, where she co-organises the Young Female Researchers in Speech Science and Technology workshops.

Advice for the next generation of female scientists Be persistent: Science is long-distance racing. For females, extra challenges appear. With persistence, confidence, and curiosity as power, you can overcome the barriers. The science community has your back: There are scholarships, awards and programs for women pursuing STEM. The roads are paved for you. If you have ever dreamed of being a scientist, donâ€™t let it go; instead fight for it. At the end of the journey, success will be waiting for you.

Researchâ€™s Impact on Society

Aviation is responsible for 5% of the total anthropogenic warming effects, including CO2 and non-CO2 effects (>60%) from NOx, water vapor, contrails, and particulate matters. In the face of the continuing expansion of air traffic, mitigation of aviationâ€™s climate impact becomes challenging but imperative. Feijia Yin is committed to making aviation greener, hence reducing the climate impact of aviation. To this end, her research interests are in aircraft engine modeling, novel engine concepts, and climate assessment of aviation technologies and operational strategies. By working on this, she aims to identify the climate-neutral pathway for future aviation development. Her recent publication on the impact of hybrid-electric aircraft on contrail coverage has drawn intensive attention and is presented as a cover page story of the Aerospace journal.

Biography

Feijia Yin is an assistant professor at the faculty of Aerospace Engineering, TU Delft. She received her PhD degree in 2016 from TU Delft on modeling and characterizing a novel multi-fuel engine concept. Afterward, Feijia started her Postdoc research on assessing the climate impact of aviation and the effective mitigation strategies from operations and technologies. In 2019, she received the prestigious NWO VENI grant to evaluate the climate impact of future aircraft propulsion technologies. Her research on verification of NOx-O3 algorithmic climate change functions received the best paper award in ICRAT 2018. She is a member of the IGTI Aero Engine Committee. She is currently involved in multiple EU projects on different sustainable aviation topics.

The science community has your back!
Strong support networks with allies are essential.

Advice for the next generation of female scientists

My advice would be to do what you love with conviction, but also to be aware that your drive and ambition are not the only factors in your success. The systems we inhabit as academics are flawed, based on a long history of bias and exclusion, and have been scientifically proven to hamper the progress of women, people of colour and differently abled people. Being aware of these factors, challenging them, and building strong support networks with allies is essential for any aspiring scientist. Be positive, be generous, be curious, and be courageous!

Research's Impact on Society

In 2019 women represented 7.7% of Chief Executive Officers (CEOs) in the EU, and just 21% of top senior executives in America's biggest firms. This "leaky pipeline" stems from a range of social/organizational issues but the extent to which the physical, designed workplace influences these factors remains unexplored. Historically offices have been designed for men, often by men, yet little research exists on how workplace design affects workplace inequality. Through archival research and interviews, this architectural history project asks how have gender roles been articulated in office design since 1950 and to what extent has this affected workplace parity.

Biography

Amy Thomas is Assistant Professor of the History of Architecture and Urban Planning at TU Delft. Her research centres on the architecture of the commercial world: the places, people and processes via which capitalism, corporations and design intersect. Her forthcoming book with MIT Press explores the post-war development of London's financial centre, the City of London. In 2020 Thomas was awarded the NWO Veni grant for the project Her Office, investigating historical connections between gender, well-being and workplace design. She is an advocate for equality, diversity and inclusion, and works with the BauHow5 alliance to improve access to architectural education.

Advice for the next generation of female scientists

I started this exciting journey many years ago. As a child, I was always curious about how things work and why humans behave the way we do. I wanted to know everything (and this tireless need for knowledge drove my parents crazy)! My determination to understand how to control machines brought me to the field of robotics, and my indefatigable need to understand human behavior drove me to the field of neuroscience. So, here is my advice: never lose curiosity. And do not listen to people who say that you will not be able to reach your goals!

Research's Impact on Society

Every year, millions of stroke survivors lose their functional autonomy due to paralysis, posing a tremendous societal and economic challenge. In absence of a cure for stroke, neuroscience evidence suggests that patients should engage in personalized, high-intensity training to maximize their recovery. I worked directly with stroke survivors and witnessed the potential for improvement that robotic devices and virtual reality can bring to their lives. Robots can deliver high-intensity training in an engaging virtual environment at a low cost. The goal of my research is to maximize patientsâ€™ recovery by employing versatile robotic devices that provide personalized physical assistance in realistic and engaging virtual environments. 

Biography

Laura Marchal-Crespo is an Associate Professor at the Department of Cognitive Robotics, Faculty 3mE, TU Delft since September 2020. She is also affiliated with the Faculty of Medicine, University of Bern, Switzerland. She obtained her M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of California at Irvine, USA, studying how robots and virtual reality can be employed to improve neurorehabilitation. Laura then joined ETH Zurich as a postdoc researcher. In 2017 she obtained a Swiss National Science Foundation (SNSF) Professorship and joined the University of Bern as medical faculty. Laura is passionate about employing her engineer skills to improve the quality of life of brain-injured patients.

Females hold up half the sky.
Be the water that flows around the rocks that are in your way.
Don't compare yourself too much with peers; rely on your own strengths.

Advice for the next generation of female scientists Take your own interests, insights and ambitions seriously. Seek your own niche, develop your own trajectory in your field rather than following what is considered relevant or fashionable by the mainstream. Work on topics you genuinely care for, and that you believe could bring your field (and society) further. Create collectives to share your insights with others, to collaborate and to remain sharp. Donâ€™t become anxious or bitter when confronted with criticism but learn from it. Be open and generous, and involve others in your success.

Researchâ€™s Impact on Society

Klaske Havik has developed a distinct research approach relating architectural and urban questions to literary language and has lectured widely on the topic in Europe and Latin America. Advocating a literary approach to architecture to address societal issues, Havik initiated the platform Writingplace, the conference Writingplace: Literary Methods in Architectural Research and Design (2013), and the Writingplace Journal for Architecture and Literature. She is Chair of the EU COST Action Writing Urban Places: New Narratives for the European City â€“ an international and interdisciplinary network that seeks for more socially inclusive and locally specific urban places through the investigation of local narratives.

Biography

Klaske Havik is Professor of Methods of Analysis and Imagination at the Faculty of Architecture and the Built Environment. Her books include Urban Literacy. Reading and Writing Architecture (2014) , Writingplace, Investigations in Architecture and Literature (2016) and Architectural Positions: Architecture, Modernity and the Public Sphere (2009). She was editor of de Architect and OASE architecture journals and founded Writingplace Journal for Architecture and Literature. Havikâ€™s literary work has appeared in numerous poetry collections and literary magazines. In 2014, she received the Dutch Architect of the Year Award. Havik is currently leading the EU COST Network Writing Urban Places.
Develop your own trajectory rather than following what is considered relevant or fashionable.
You need to gather people around you with whom you can communicate and work, forming a real team of which the members mutually reinforce each other.
Neelke Doorn focuses on ethical issues in water governance and climate change.
Alina Rwei develops novel biomedical technologies for next-generation medicine.

Sepideh Ghodrat investigates the properties of materials (alloys, polymers and composites) and applies them as active elements in designing shape morphing objects like deployable structures, self-sizable adaptable shoes, self-sizable grips, self-regulating jackets and soft mobile devices.
Catholijn Jonker is dedicated to creating teamwork between humans agents and robots in a way that brings about a co-evolution between humans and technology.
Klaske Havik advocates a literary approach to architecture to address societal issues.
Continue to be curious and inspired for work, even if other people and pupils do not understand.
You can always become a Don(na) Quixote.
Do not let anyone tell you what you can and cannot do
Aleksandra Lekic's research topics are related to the circuit theory, control, and stability analysis of the power converters and hybrid power systems.
AimÃ©e Sakes focusses on the development of innovative medical instruments and robots inspired by nature.
Be open and outspoken of your opinion. Then bring more solid evidence and calculation to the table.

I was told frequently to tune down, give up, or focus my energy differently....still while this path sometimes felt like a lonely, uphill battle, it also gave me energy back. Listen to that last aspect: never give up on what makes you tick.
See the person behind the gender.

"Female voices are less likely to be accurately processed by voice recognition software and artificial intelligence assistants, because these programs are trained on datasets in which women are underrepresented (Perez, 2019). Google’s speech-recognition software, for example, is significantly more likely to accurately transcribe male speech, compared to female speech (Tatman, 2020). A similar pattern has been found in voice recognition software used to automatically score clinical trials, to select job applicants and for the voice command system in cars (The Guardian, 2019; Tatman, 2017). "--excerpt from "One Size Fits Some", a 2020 Master's Thesis on gender bias at the TU Delft by Maartje van Proosdij advised by Prof. dr. B.F. van Eekelen and Dr. ir. A.G.C. van Boeijen.
